title: 110_hr3893
content: The "Connect America Now Act" may be cited as the official title of this legislation. Key findings are outlined in the Act. The "Connect America Now Act" recognizes the importance of broadband services for economic development, public safety, healthcare, education, and quality of life. It emphasizes the need for continued progress in broadband deployment to maintain competitiveness and create business and job growth. The Act also supports partnerships between the public and private sectors to enhance broadband services and information technology. The "Connect America Now Act" emphasizes the importance of broadband services and information technology for economic development, public safety, healthcare, education, and quality of life for residents and businesses of the Nation. SEC. 3. ENCOURAGING STATE INITIATIVES TO IMPROVE BROADBAND. The grant program aims to ensure affordable broadband access, increase technology literacy, empower local technology teams, and promote broadband investment. The Secretary of Commerce will award grants for development based on peer review results. The grant program, under subsection (d), supports statewide initiatives for broadband availability and adoption. Grants are awarded competitively, and eligible entities must submit applications and provide matching funds. The Secretary will require peer review for technical and scientific evaluation. The regulations require technical and scientific peer review groups to review grant applications, provide results to the Secretary of Commerce, and certify confidentiality agreements to prevent unauthorized disclosure of information. Grants awarded to eligible entities support broadband availability and adoption initiatives. A grant awarded to eligible entities supports broadband availability and adoption initiatives by conducting baseline assessments, tracking low service deployment areas, identifying barriers to adoption, and assessing demand and supply for broadband services. To support broadband availability and adoption, grants are awarded to create local technology planning teams in each county or designated region. These teams consist of members from various sectors to measure technology use, set goals for improvement, and ensure that supply meets demand for services. To achieve improved technology use, a tactical business plan with specific recommendations for online application development and demand creation is developed. Collaboration with broadband service providers and information technology companies is encouraged to deploy services in unserved and underserved areas. Programs are established to enhance computer ownership and Internet access for these populations, along with collecting and analyzing detailed market data. The program aims to collect and analyze market data on broadband service demand, facilitate information exchange between public and private sectors, and create a geographic inventory map of broadband service in each state. This includes identifying gaps in service availability and assessing statewide broadband deployment. Eligible entities in each state may not receive new grants for these activities. The program aims to collect and analyze market data on broadband service demand, facilitate information exchange between public and private sectors, and create a geographic inventory map of broadband service in each state. Eligible entities in each state may not receive new grants for these activities if they have received prior grant awards for the same activities in the previous 4 consecutive years. Recipients of grants must submit reports on fund usage to the Secretary of Commerce. Definitions include "eligible entity" as a nonprofit organization or public sector entity working with state agencies and private sector partners, and "nonprofit organization" as an organization meeting specific criteria. An eligible organization for the program must be a nonprofit described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, with no earnings benefiting individuals, a proven record in deploying broadband services, and a board not majority government-affiliated. The term "broadband service" refers to any service connecting to the public Internet with a data transmission rate of at least 200 kilobits per second. $40,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. The Act does not grant additional regulatory authority over broadband service providers.
